Executive Summary



A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

Future Foam, Inc. is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards. An appropriate response to releases of TDI is in the written Risk Management Program. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. 



B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Future Foam, Inc.is a urethane foam manufacturing facility which produces various type of flexible urethane foam products located in Elkhart, IN. The facility fabricates some of the urethane foam into various finished products.

Flexible urethane foam is a product made by combining various chemicals that undergo a chemical reaction. The finished product is produced in a variety of colors, thicknesses, and densities.  One of chemicals used is 2, 4-Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI). The TDI is stored in five (5) 6,000-gallon TDI Storage Tanks and four (4) 12,600 gallon TDI Storage Tanks within the tank storage area and delivered via tanker truck.  The TDI Storage tanks have a combined storage capacity of 80,400-gallons. The 80,400-gallons of TDI equates to 817,668 pounds of TDI.  For safety reasons, these tanks are never filled past 95%.  When including this 95% limit, the Maximum TDI on-site is 76,380 gallons (776,785 pounds).  Conservatively, the total amount in CDX is rounded up to 777,000 pounds. 

The EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) is part of the Clean Air Act and applies to a process storing a specified chemical above a threshold quantity. The chemicals and threshold quantities are specified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68. One such chemical is Toluene 2, 4-Diisocynate (TDI) in excess of 10,000 pounds which is used as an ingredient in the manufacturing process.

After reviewing the facility operations

and the RMP regulations, it was determined that the entire facility is considered one process.  Based on the Off Site Consequence Analysis, facility processes and applicable regulations, it was determined that the facility is subject to Program 1 of the RMP regulations.



C.  Accidental Release Prevention and Specific Prevention Steps:

Future Foam, Inc.is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards.  An appropriate response to releases of TDI is in the written Risk Management Program. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. 

Future Foam, Inc.'s specific prevention steps include:

1. Develop, review and update operating and maintenance procedures for the TDI process.

2. Provide the appropriate training for TDI process operators, maintenance personnel, and emergency response personnel.

3. Conduct timely investigations of all incidents involving the TDI process.

4. Conduct RMP Compliance audits as per RMP regulations.



D. Hazard Assessment: (OCA)

The RMP requires Future Foam, Inc. to evaluate the maximum potentially affected area for accidents involving TDI for a worst-case release scenario and an alternative scenario.

The worst-case release is highly improbable since it involves the combination of a certain set of conditions for a large release of the chemical without any employee intervention.  Because the assumptions required for the worst-case analysis are very conservative, the results likely will be very conservative. The endpoints specified for regulated toxic substances are intended to be protective of the general public. The distance to the endpoint estimated under worst-case conditions should not be considered an area in which the public would likely be in danger; instead, it is intended to provide an estimate of the maximum possible area that mig

ht be affected in the unlikely event of catastrophic accident. EPA intends the estimated distances to provide a basis for discussion among the regulated community, emergency responders, and the public, rather a basis for any specific actions.



A catastrophic release of one 12,600-gallon storage tank of 2,4-toluene diisocyanate (2,4-TDI) into the secondary containment located inside a permanent building has been identified as the worst-case release and was considered in the hazard assessment.  It is assumed the catastrophic release would release the entire contents of the tank. The impact distance from the worst-case scenario has been estimated using EPA's ALOHA Model.  The ALOHA Method estimates a distance to the endpoint of 20 yards for the worse-case release scenario. The impact distance does not extend beyond the facility property line.

    

The alternative scenario is not required due to the worst-case scenario not extending beyond the property line.   

         

E. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

Operating Procedures: Future Foam, Inc. has developed written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at each operation where TDI is utilized. These written operating procedures are consistent with the process safety information for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety and health considerations, safety systems and their functions. The operating procedures are readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the TDI system. These operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice. Future Foam, Inc. has developed and implemented safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; opening process equipment or piping; and control entrance into the TDI facility.

Training: Future Foam, Inc. will continue to provide training for each employ

ee associated with the TDI system. This training will include an overview of the process and operating procedures as outlined in 40 CFR 68.54.  Refresher training is provided every three (3) years or more often as necessary. Future Foam, Inc. documents and maintains records of employee training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.

Mechanical Integrity: Future Foam, Inc should develop a written preventive maintenance program to maintain the on-going integrity of the equipment used in the TDI process (i.e., storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, etc); additionally, inspections, testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance are addressed.

Each person who has responsibilities to perform maintenance on the TDI system components will receive training at Future Foam, Inc Foam Technologies every three (3) years or more often if necessary.

Compliance Audits: Future Foam, Inc. will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of 40 CFR, Part 68 every three (3) years. The compliance audit will be conducted by an Future Foam, Inc Foam Technologies person knowledgeable in the TDI system.  A report of the findings of the audit will be developed.  Future Foam, Inc. will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected.  Records of the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports will be maintained.

Incident Investigation: Future Foam, Inc. will investigate each incident, which results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of TDI. Incident investigations will be initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The incident investigation team will consist of at least one Future Foam, Inc Foam Technologies person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor. A report will be prepared at t

he conclusion of the investigation, and Future Foam, Inc. will promptly address and resolve the incident findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions will be documented. Incident investigation reports will be retained for five (5) years.



F. Five-year Accident History

Within the past five years, the process has had no accidental releases that caused offsite impacts provided in the RMP rule (40 CFR 68.10(b)(1).  



G. Emergency Response Program

Future Foam, Inc. has developed and implemented an emergency response program for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. 

This program includes the following elements: 

1. An emergency management plan, which is maintained on site and contains at Future Foam, Inc Foam Technologies the following elements:

   a. Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies;

   b. Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary for   

      Accidental exposures; and

   c. Procedures for emergency response after an accidental release of TDI.

2. Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection.

3. Training for all employees in relevant procedures; and

4. Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency management plan to     

 Reflect changes at Future Foam, Inc. and to ensure that employees are informed of changes.



H. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

In an attempt to insure a continual improvement in the facility worker protection and release prevention programs, training will be conducted at Future Foam, Inc. every three years on this program.  This program requires the attendance of personnel whose job is related to the TDI system.  Additionally, audits will be performed as specified in the RMP plan, which requires Future Foam, Inc. to assess areas of the RMP plan that may need to be changed or improved.
